content.description: This is a wide (OW) crack that runs up Exit / Chickenhead wall.  It's hard to miss. Try to use pure OW style, and keep away from the face holds that would make it considerably easier.
content.protection: You could TR this, but once you're in it, you're probably wedged pretty good.  A pad is nice. Grunting helps. Long pants are necessary.
content.location: Technically it goes to the top, but it quits being worthwhile after the crack peters out.  Downclimb from here, or finish it off and walk off just to the north.

content.description:
This climb follows the black streak on the slab to the left of

Ship's Prow

.  The climbing is in the 5.6-5.7 range.  There are a number of easy straight up and traverse variations on this slab.  The top outs are a little loose, so you should consider traversing off or down climbing.

There is no gear at the top for a TR on this wall.
content.location:
Slabster is located on the slab to the left of

Ship's Prow

.

content.description: Dyno from the underclings at the bottom of the crack to the jugs up and left (just right of the crimp on Standard). Then top out on big holds.
content.location: This is on the right side of the prow. Start at the bottom of the crack.

content.description:
A classic committing route that starts up the "

Curving Crack

" but busts straight up at it's apex and over the roof above. Don't blow out on this one; the worst climbing injury in my life was trying to spot some drunken "climber" who blew out at the roof. (The Beta is to grab the undercling with your LEFT! hand and toe bar the crack with your left toe.) A lot easier now when a flake broke and formed a huge new hold for your right foot.
Start in the crack, but make a long reach to a crimp from the large undercling just before the crack jogs right. Continue up jugs to top.
content.location:
It is just right of the classic

Finger Ripper

.

content.description: Climb the thinner face holds (not the arete itself) just to the right of the ship's prow arete.  Once you get your feet up on the face you'll have this one in the bag.
content.protection: A pad is nice for this hardpacked flat landing.

content.description:
After getting warmed up on the "Standard"

Ship's Prow

(

Ship's Prow Right

by your description) and doing the Finger Ripper try this. Straight up between them, no holds on the other two allowed before the big horizontal ledge at mid-height. If you thought Finger Ripper was sharp, wait 'till you work the opening moves on this; a total tip shredder! A little reachy for me at 5'9" but a really nice hard route up this classic face.
content.protection: A pad is nice for the last few hard moves before the horizontal break.

content.description: The obvious prow along the ridge, just uphill from the north slabs of the eliminator boulder is picturesque.  Climb starting on the left side via jugs on the prow and immediately on the left, then layback on the left side until the first break.  Tiptoe along the prow with jugs to the top!
content.protection: A few anklebreakers here, and easy topout is highball (20+ feet).  Good spot(s) a must for those near their limit, pads nice too.

content.description: Climb on the very small crimps and sidepulls to the right of Ship's Prow Left and to the left of the curving crack - this lovely crack is off for this fun balancy problem.  If you don't rip your fingers on the first small and second smaller crimp, or the small undercling (which some actually use in their sequence, myself included) then you'll might just have some fun pulling on the opposing sidepulls before reaching the jugs.
content.protection: Pad and a spotter is nice for the harpack flat landing.  Topout is very easy highball.

content.description:
As described in the

NCCC

guide for the area, this problem starts with matched hands on the Africa-shaped chunk of darker rock just to the right of the arete and moves pretty much directly up from there, quickly reaching considerably easier climbing.
content.protection: A pad is nice. Don't fall off the top; it's a long way down.
content.location: This one starts just a couple of feet right of the arete. It is not quite a sit-start, rather a "hanging" start.

content.description:
This is a short, but enjoyable, eliminate on the west-facing wall immediately left of

Exit Wall

.

The line ascends the black streak utilizing primarily tiny edges and sidepulls, along with a couple shallow pockets near the top of the problem - hang on through the slope-y, fun top out.

And, since this is Rotary Park, no problem would be complete without a couple "rules" - the left edge of the slab houses a small left-facing corner - any holds within about 18 inches of the mini-arete are "off" for full value V2; this basically eliminates a nice starting foothold and a bulge-y feature about 8 feet up the wall.
content.protection: The landing is rocky and a little steep, but looks worse than it is; in all likelihood you won't be dyno-ing up the slab.  That said, a pad is worthwhile.

content.description:
To the left of the

Exit Wall

, between it and the

Exit Wall Slab

, is a very dirty dihedral.

With a jagged finger to hand-sized crack tucked away in back of the right side, a fin like projection in the middle of the dihedral, and sides that seem to wrap around in a chimney-like way, this easy problem gives a nice to change of pace to the crimpy lines around the park.

V0 may be a stretch for this problem, but it will likely cause new climbers to think a little. I found no obvious crux, just some fun moves made a little less secure by lots of dirt. I'm sure a stiff bristled brush or some traffic would clean it up very quickly.
content.protection: The ground slopes away below this and the V2 slab next to it, but there is a relatively flat spot big enough for a pad. It's not a very high topout.
content.location:
The

Exit Wall

, also known as the Chickenhead Wall, is North of The Prow just past the tree. The dihedral is just north of that, around the corner (climber's left).

content.description: Exit wall starts on the arete on the north facing wall of the "Exit Wall" area. Leave the arete and climb up and left to the top.  The landing is poor as you top out on this highball problem.
content.protection: A pad and spot would be nice....
content.location:
Exit Wall climbs the north facing wall about 50ft north of the

Ship's Prow

.

content.description: Climb Curving Crack to final horizontal and reach above and right to good incut, work feet up and crank for the top.  This is just right of the Gill Reach.
content.protection: Not a great landing, spotter and pad will make safer but not completely.

content.description:
Climbs the traversing, aptly named crack on the main ridge above the Eliminator boulder, just right of the Finger Ripper.  Start at the lowest left portion of the crack, lieback, jam and otherwise climb it to it's bifurcation and either take the high or low version of this crack.

The low version follows a horizontal finger crack, with one's feet just off the deck.  The higher version leads to another horizontal seam.

Variations, do a different problem ... the Gill Reach (V2 - highball and height dependent) off a distinct undercling or traverse right to  another problem Easier Reach (V0+) off an incut, or climb right on the final horizontal seam and traverse right to an easy crack (topout or downclimb this).
content.protection: Climbs above a few rocks, a good spotter and a pad will be nice.

content.description: Bucketland climbs the juggy face to the right of the arete on the Exit Wall.  Every hold is positive, so the best descent is to reverse the route.  A fun easy highball problem....
content.location:
Bucketland climbs juggy face of the "Exit Wall" area.  The Exit Wall is about 50ft north of the

Ship's Prow

.
